reviewText:
If you like the first three Final Fantasy games, you'll like this. It is originally a Flash game, but evolved to become what I think a great classic. It's combat in particular is what I think a high point in the game, the graphics and especially those auto cast skills that appear at random to bombard your enemies will always make you smile. You can have a hat that randomly calls in a tank to blast an enemy with its cannon, or a shirt that calls another tank to rain down machine gun fire to enemies. There's even an attachment that randomly calls a cat to charge at enemies, or radio in airdrop to give a medpack to someone, or cast some random element skills like poison gas, or even an airstrike that drops random stuffs, like a nuclear bomb.

Of course, many boss units have some OP skills as well, like an orbital particle cannon, or some insane defensive skill that switch profile whenever hit by a skill. It is much more variable and over the top than the early FF games, yet maintains the same light heart atmosphere. Your characters will even chatter whenever something interesting or over the top happens. What's more, nobody will disapprove of the ability to summon a blackhole that can suck everyone, good or bad, in.

Light hearted RPG doesn't get much better than this. If you like this type of game, this is a must have.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent game. Best indy rpg I've played, and definitly one of the best jrpgs I've tried(up there with Golden Sun and Dragonquest)
It has remarkably detailed combat, and usign weaknesses and resistances is about the only way to take down some of the tougher foes.
It also has a lot of hidden items ^w^ And many easter eggs.
It also uses an unusual system for encoutners, with most battles only happening if you target the foe and start it yourself, with most batles having preset compositions(a nice change from the usual random encoutners of jrpgs).

reviewText:
crazy good game considering it was developed mostly by one guy. has everything that makes indie rpgs good including:

rad music straight outta newgrounds
clever references to games as old as ff1 and as new as minecraft
really good animation and art everywhere
gear upgrades from loot
enemies are very well designed and its easy to tell their strengths and weaknesses just by looking at them
grind/gear curve is perfect
very easy to influence game difficulty
it does have its problems though, mostly due to being ported from flash. moving the mouse anywhere on screen drops the FPS to 1 (known bug) and the game starts dropping a bunch of frames after playing for a couple of hours (only fix is restarting game). there's also no controller support which is sad but still not a gamebreaker.

if you want a fun indie by weebs
date: for weebs" rpg that doesn't require much commitment (and you've already played neptunia)
recommended: support scottish developers and get this. it's a good deal at the base price and at 50% off you're robbing the poor guy."

reviewText: Anyone who was already a fan of this series who might feel weird about spending money on what was an internet flash game might want to give it a second thought. This game boasts 25 hours of gameplay which is around twice as long as most big budget games' campaigns and it had new game plus as well. The same humor that this series is known for is fully intact and the art done for the cutscenes is simple but definitely depicts the quirky nature of the characters and situations. For the harcore RPG players this game starts with higher difficulty modes to ensure that you are challenged right off the bat. To anyone who is a fan of the series I say you should definitely pick this up to show your support for the guy who has been doing these games for years now and to those who aren't familiar with this series I suggest you go find the other games online before you make a real judgement about this game. You won't be dissappointed :)

reviewText:
I absolutely enjoy this game. I honestly find it to be one of my favorite Turn-based rpgs out there.

It has alot of heart, the gameplay is really fun, and the difficulty is there. Not to mention the surprising amount of depth to the combat as you progress further into the game. The Steam and Kongregate Premium versions have a pretty nifty sum of extras for the more devoted fans of the game to unlock as well. Plus, you get the soundtrack as an added bonus if you buy it here. Which really helps add to the value of the game.

If you are like me, then you will get a good 20+ hours out of this game, and that was before I got the premium edition. And with the new NG+ feature, New Battle Area, Survival and Boss Rush modes, and the new equipment and Skills to check out, there is no doubt in my mind that it will leech even more time from me.

reviewText:
A bit about Epic Battle Fantasy 4:
- turn based RPG with max. 4 Characters (3active fighting + 1backup)
-no grinding for equipment just some for upgrading them
-Supports mouse and keyboard controlls (you will need a mouse no matter what)
-Good music
-Epic Battle against foes and bosses
-inclueds premium content + Soundtrack
-lots of humor
-newgame+

You can test the gameplay on sites like Armorgames, Kongregate ...
But please bear in mind that the Steam version has:
-improved graphics and sounds
-cloud saving
-fullscreen resolutions
-just the basic gameplay is identical

To those who think:  why buying this game on steam when you can play it for free in the internet/ is cheaper if you just buy it from Kongregate"
A simple calculation: Premium Pack on Kongregate( cost about 8$) +Digital Soundtrack ( cost 12$) =20$
cost on Steam Premium Pack + Digital Soundtrack = 11.99$!!!"
voteText: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game that doesn't look great but is rated 98% on Steam, uh..? Okay, let's try the Flash version... Ah, the agony, you have to point and click to move the character around, they're moving on a grid and you get ugly icons everywhere you point at... My, my. The character designs aren't exactly good... Okay, since these are both one-man projects, I'll at least say that it looks much better than Undertale. It also beats it in terms of laughs and overall complexity.
Really. It's absolutely hilarious, and also excrutiatingly overwhelming at the beginning of the game. Ah, those crafting materials...!

After an hour I decided to buy the Steam version, and couldn't stop playing it ever since. This is nothing like a RPG Maker game, it seems to use its very own engine (which, amusingly, is quite slow even on a high-end PC... Thankfully it's still playable). This has a lot of advantages.
It pays respects to its elders but never tries to be lazy about anything. My main complaint? It's a very difficult game... If you want to 100% it, you'll suffer. A lot. Be prepared to spend tens of hours on it. I'll just be happy with at least two thirds of the achievements. If you don't mind not getting everything, then... I get it's doable. But you'll still need to grind a lot, or use a money cheat to buy all of the items you need.

And this was my 42nd Steam review, a milestone for any self-respecting geek. Not my finest hour, though!

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is an incredibly fun adventure roughly based off of games such as the early Final Fantasy games. As its title implies, there are also three entries before it... there are also two spin-offs. EBF4 has a flash version that's free to play, but you will have to pay for the Battle Mountain zone regardless, and the flash version tends to be rather laggy at times. Unfortunately, due to the earlier three games containing things that would bring its developer, Matt Roszak, into legal trouble (most notably the first game having a few pokemon for summons, and the final boss of the first game being Goku), they will not be appearing on Steam.

Plot
In between the events of the third game and this one, the heroes, Matt, Natalie (Natz for short), and Lance, turn to a life of crime, since they lack the funds to buy food. They think that this is justified due to them saving the world before, although this is a rather flimsy excuse. They finally go too far when they steal an important jewel from Greenwood Village, causing her to seek them and finally deliver justice to them... only to learn that they did not steal the jewel. Anna must team up with the heroes, and track down the thief before he/she/it/they can steal the other two jewels and summon forth Godcat, who will destroy the world.

...It's rather bare-bones, and can rather easily be ignored in the favor of picking fights with wild animals. Aside from a few rather minor references to the third game, you can easily jump into the game's plot without playing any other games in the EBF series. Interestingly enough, the entire series runs on the plot structure of Stop this thing by beating it to a pulp
date:
although this game diverges itself from this plot a little more.

Gameplay
Gameplay is split up into two areas: The overworld and combat.

In the overworld, you can walk around, accepting quests to get items for complete strangers with the promise of some stuff in return, harrasing the wildlife, stealing items from treasure boxes, and buying items to prepare for combat. When one wishes to enter the combat phase of gameplay, one simply clicks on an enemy on the map. If one goes to the options tab, one can switch between using the keyboard and the mouse to travel on the map.

In combat, you have a myriad of standard JRPG skills, including several that are based off of elements. As one of the game's tips says, attack enemies until they die. If red numbers appear, that means the element of that attack is pretacualy effective against that foe. If grey numbers appear, that means the foe is either immune or resists the attack. One can also use the Scanbot summon to reveal the weaknesses of these enemies, revealing their weaknesses and stat totals for all enemies of that type. Battles may be split into multiple waves, too. In one of the lower points of the game, your party's turns are not refreshed at the start of each wave, which can result in up to five enemies getting free attacks if you use your last action to kill an enemy. This is especially bothersome with the final boss, who will kill" itself after a few turns on the waves where it's invulnerable

reviewText:
I'm always a fan of Final Fantasy style games, the ones where you take turns doing damage to your enemies, and them to you. What I especially like about the Epic Battle Fantasy games however, is the differences it has that make it stand out as a game. For instance, at the highest levels, your weapons that you've had since the beginning are still options to use for battle, instead of other games where your starter weapon was probably sold at the first shop for some extra cash. For the final bosses as well, unlike the FF games, where simple grinding could make anything easy, this game relies on intelligent strategy to beat a boss.

You can't simply use brute force to take down an enemy here, it requires actual thinking. You have to consider:

-What weapons do I use?
-What's their weakness?
-What armour do I wear to compensate for their skills and mine?
-What skills do I use, and which special abilities (Only one person gets it, but you choose) gets which skills.

All of this, a decent storyline, great music, good characters with unique personalities, and a vast world are all reasons why Epic Battle Fantasy 4 should be considered a great buy.

reviewText: This installment of the EBF series is by far the best. Its absolutely worth every penny.

So many great little details and some game and anime references. Menus are easy to navigate and the game is animated extremely well. There's much more praise I could give the game but I don't wanna potentially spoil anything. Definitely a must buy with it's price.

reviewText:
Great turn-based RPG. Long-term strategy in choosing who gets which abilities, thus focusing each character around certain roles, and shorter-term stuff in deciding when you need to buff and debuff in-battle. And unless you're playing on Easy, you DO need to buff. (Which means the game has difficulty pretty much just right, especially as you can choose between Easy, Normal, Hard, and Epic.)
The dialogue is also very entertaining, the art style is nice, and if the enemy design isn't good there'll be witty comments on how unoriginal it is.

tl;dr: Good difficulty, good gameplay, good music, good graphics, good dialogue. Get.

reviewText:
Well that was a fun ride.
For those who enjoy turn-based RPG, then this is the game for you.
This game comes complete with
- Hilarious characters
- Awesome skills, spells, and summons
- Tons of equipments for a variety of combinations to use in battle
- Awesome soundtrack by HFX
- New Game+ for even more replay value
I've been keeping track of the EBF series since the second game. (And I still haven't beaten them on Epic)
And it makes me happy as a fan to see how each new game improves compared to the previous game.
This game was made by an awesome guy who has been making awesome free games.
Buying this game would help out a ton for Matt for all his hard work.
Even if you can't buy it, then you can play the free version on kongregate, along with every other games he has made.
The experience is still the same, no matter what version of EBF4 you play.

reviewText: Like JRPGs? Anime? Honest to goodness humor? Well good for you, a game with all of that! Not too frequently do you see such a good game. The music is great and diverse, and really conveys the area. The art is cute, but not so much that you feel sorry for the enemies you kill by the millions. The humor is great, and the gameplay? AWESOME. Getting through with brute force is impossible, but you can't be weak and expect a strategy with no force backing it up to work. The game is hard but very possible, even on Epic. Extra versions of the bosses are insanely hard but give great rewards. Even with the free version there, this game is worth more than the big, expensive games you see all so often in stores. 11 out of 10.

reviewText:
First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/epic-battle-fantasy-4-first-impressions/

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a cute turn-based RPG. The art is fantastic, especially for a game of this genre.

The gameplay is simple, similar to what one would expect from a game of the genre. You've got the exploring aspect and the turn-based combat aspect, both of which are reminiscent of classic RPG flash games (Dragon Fable anyone?). It's nothing too special, but it's fun enough to not warrant a complaint from me.

The game's music was fantastic. I really enjoyed it and look forward to getting a copy of the soundtrack for future listening. Oh, and the artstyle, which was also very well done. Just like any other RPG, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 comes packed with a massive (and somewhat complex) skill system. It may have taken a while to get used to it, but it's certainly one of the game's positives.

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a great game, earning my recommendation. The artstyle may turn a few people away, but the game itself is fantastic (and besides, that artstyle should be selling more than it already is, right?).

reviewText:
A witty game, hearkening back to the older RPG's of yesteryear, where the battle system was refined, and the enemies made sense for the setting (no, not really, but just roll with it).  In this game, you command a three of four warriors at a time, and fight for the safety of the world.

Uses a turn based combat system, where speed is not a factor.  Your team goes, then their team, then yours, etc...
The summon system works well as any character can use it, but you still have to watch the summon's resource bar.
A large array of weapons, armors, gear, skills, and spells for you to arm yourself against the monsterous waves of enemies that block your path.  Will you stand tall and face the challenge? Will you fight in this Epic Battle Fantasy?

reviewText: This game has become one of my guilty pleasures. Although it's a port of a Freemium Flash game, it runs smoothly and is thankfully devoid of a Cash Shop. The graphics are whimsically cute, and the gameplay can be considered JRPG-lite for Westerners...as it has everything you'd expect in a JRPG but without the insane grind (you can make it through the entire game within 12-14 hours as opposed to hundreds of hours in a typical JRPG). The humor and use of standard JRPG tropes is comical to where you can't help but smile and giggle incessently while playing (down to the non-apologetic blatant remix of the victory theme from FFVII).  It may not be a hard-core JRPG, but it is a delightfully fun tip of the hat to classic JRPGs. It's definitely worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
Great fun->
I usually skip over all types of round-bases-battle-RPGs but I'm glad I made an exception here. EBF4 is a tongue-in-cheek RPG with hilarious characters who dress as stereotypical pirates, rangers or red mages. On the over-world map you collect hidden goodies, explore branching ways and follow the farce of a storyline. If you choose to bump into an enemy the fighting starts, no tedious random encounters after any x steps. Also heroes slowly heal after battle for convenience and most creatures respawn.

The battle system isn't boring but really fun with lots of different skills, weapons, equipment, usable items.
Skills are unlocked and upgraded with skill points. Levels are gained by experience. Weapons and Armor are found or bought in shops and upgraded with items. There are also summons usable by anyone, limit breaks and specials" which are skills you can assign to complement a characters skill set like a fire attack or a heal spell.

You may try out the EBF game series on some websites for free to understand how the game works."

reviewText:
This game I bought because the different art styles were all cute and interesting. What followed was a shockingly good experience that I really didn't see coming.

This game is based on RPGs like Final Fantasy and Golden Sun, but where they can be very slow (the former, particularly), this one is incredibly fast paced. I've played a fair amount of FFxiii, but I managed to catch up to my playtime for that game in a much shorter span due to how enveloping this game can be; I've wiled away more than one night by just playing the story of this.

Grinding is possible, but wholly unneeded. It seems most of the enemies have some kind of scaling, but maybe I was just at the perfect level for everything... Not being able to tell which it is is a very positive thing.
It also have a Game+ mode where you just restart the story with all your levels, skills and equipment. This is a nice feature, but I wish it had asked first as I was close to a few end game achieves that reset with the story.

The actual gameplay is, as I said, fast and flowing. A little less dependence on the mouse would have been nice (you need to click to exit combat, for example), but I still love the way this game controls. Although the interface is mind-bogglingly complicated when you first see it, everything has its place and all fits together surprisingly well for a system as detailed as this. There're skill trees, equipment collecting, weapon and armour modifications, 'flair' trinkets, stat boosters, element resistance, buffs/debuffs... You get the point. But by a few hours into the game, I understood the majority of it.

Character balancing was a bit off for me... I dunno if it was bad use of stat items and skills, but my best fighter was also my best healer and had half the max health of my others. Due to the sheer number of options, I found it hard to keep it straight in my head which character should have which (I did consider making some kind of spreadsheet, but decided against it), but I managed to complete the game on normal difficulty without too much hassle. Don't think I ever lost a fight.

Enough about gameplay, what about the story and tone? The tone is brilliant. Spot on. Phenomenal. It'd be worth playing this for the characters' interactions alone. It plays beautifully with RPG and gaming tropes, references are everywhere and as I said at the beginning, the art style is amazing. Cutscenes are done in a felt-style looping animation, battles are anime and overworld travel are chibi things. They all work surprisingly well together and give the game a very lighthearted feel that becomes all the better when the team encounter horrific atrocities.

Also there's a little easter egg that I stumbled upon entirely by accident, but could NOT stop laughing at. I won't spoil it. But damn. It just epitomises the game.

Overall, this is a fantastic light RPG that is deep enough in gameplay to be elevated beyond the flash game it is and become one of my favourites. Resolution options are terrible, mind, and it isn't integrated with steam very well. Still. Amazing game.

reviewText: I bought EBF4 a couple of days ago and the Steam Sale, it didn't look too special but apparently many people recommended it. What I got was an quite an suprisingly amazing game, a good looking and fun RPG, not only that but pretty addictive too. I know this is made on Flash, and free to play on some sites on the internet I still feel like it's worth it, for the price and it's estimated play time (about 11-12 Hours in, still not done), definitly if it's on sale. You should really try it if you like a great classic RPG with some good humor, references and fun gameplay.\n\n9.5/10 Definitly worth it.

reviewText: I'm known to HATE turn-based combat, but the Epic Battle Fantasy Series is the exception. I don't know what it is about the games that makes me love them to bits... I guess it's the characters and the wholeheartedness of it all. What I feel: Kupo wants to make these games for the love of making them. Also, you can't say that the characters haven't had any development. I remember how Lance joined the team (not in EBF4) - which was hilarious. Then there's Anna who learned to tolerate Matt's love to ste- err, take Free Samples" whenever he wants. A love development can really complicate the narrative if mis-handled

reviewText:
Do you like turn-based RPGs? Do you like silly dialogue? Do you like stupid yet lovable protagonists who steal everything not bolted to the ground? Do you like clicking on women's chests? Do you like silly/cool outfits? Do you like references to cool stuff? Do you like cats?

If the answer to any of those is yes, you're gonna like this game.

But if you're still not sure, then maybe head on over to Kongregate and try the flash version. It's basically the same game, but without a bonus area that you have to pay for on the flash version. And then maybe buy it if you like it. I think it's worth it.

reviewText:
This is a standard RPG with its selling point probably being its humor. It's pretty addicting.

The two best things about this game:

- When you get a medal, notifications appear on your steam client, the game itself (satisfying sound effect included), and if you have ASTATS open in your browser in the background, it'll appear there, too.

- What's even better, is when in game, you're fighting an enemy and it barely lived as your turn ended, then it gets struck by lightning and dies, ending the battle. Or even better, it gets crushed by a falling mammoth out of nowhere. Or two of them.

If you feel that's underwhelming, maybe this isn't for you. I recommend you play the free flash games, Epic Battle Fantasy 1~4, to see how you like it before buying it. They're on Kongregate and other flash game sites.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Really enjoyable game, would absolutely recommend.

It's fun, quirky and let's you take it at your own pace.
If you're a m3g4 l33t MLG H4rdc0r3 gamer then you may find it a bit easy, I boosted it up to hard for a bit more of a challange and I usually freaking suck at games. But I'd suggest hard mode when you get your bearings.
But really it's a lovely game to play, it's not stressful at all (Except maybe mid-boss fight) but even then you can drop in and out of battles with no penalty. It also gives you the option to come up with battle strategies that rely on your team working together to take down your foes, or you can just wale on them until death happens.

Anyway if you're thinking about buying this game enough that you're reading this then I'd say get it. Unless you're a scaredy sisspot that is.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy is a story set in a fantasy land that encapsulates total humour. It's powerful role playing essentials prove that an RPG does not have to be made with great graphics or new complicated battle mechanics - it just needs a firm storyline such as this.

The story unfolds with four heroes that find each other along the journey, fight monsters, and as usual, attempt to claim world peace from this unseemingly harmless boss - the Godcat. Throughout the way, dry R16 humour develops throughout the story, and even when you are engaging in difficult battles, somewhat the characters randomly crack jokes in a light hearted manner. Hmm...

The system is brilliant. Brilliant in the sense that the forging and money systems go hand-in-hand nicely unlike many other games that introduce poverty into the heroes. Summons actually help a lot, and battle statuses are not just those nice symbols floating on your heads - they actually kill you. Simple but effective.

Music is fine, although the tunes are reminiscent of popular music. Canon in D - main theme. Enjoyable but I didn't love it as much and it somewhat did not match the situations.

Overall, a must try for fantasy fans. Also has a very high replay value.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
30 Hours later - I beat it and completed the side mission battles (which were harder than the last boss.)

The first 15 hours of this game was really good - a classic turn based RPG combat with some internet humor thrown in.  You have three people in battle and one back up.  You buff, cast magic, and attack - what you would expect.

The core of the combat is fun, but in the later stages of the game: it becomes a little bit of a chore at times.  I didn't find the game to be hard - infact it was easy for an RPG, even the bonus areas.  It was very easy to stay alive and slowly reduce a big boss over time.... however that being said - I have years & years of classic RPG experience and most of the close calls" I bounced back quickly.  I actually died once just to see what happened.

Anyway - this is a fun
recommended: RPG style game with a lot of spells
hoursPlayed: summons
voteText: and monsters to fight.  Not a lot outside of the combat but enough to keep you entertained for awhile.\n\nI would recommend it!"

reviewText: I recommend this game if you love turn-based RPGs with some addictive skill progression, secret loot, and a huge overworld. I wouldn't take the story seriously, but for what it is, it does give the journey some nice context and results in some quirky bosses that are fun to fight. I've spent so much time experimenting and upgrading my equipment and skills in order to find the best way to fight certain enemies, and it's made me love RPGs all over again. Definitely worth the price in playtime alone!

reviewText: Really didn't expect to enjoy this half as much as I actually am. It's funny as hell! After getting a tad bored with South Park : TSOT I really needed something that played in a similar way to fill that craving for a good RPG. This just does it for me. The art style is over the top and fits the game perfectly, the writing is sharp as hell and the mechanics are solid and really enjoyable.\n\nThis is a welcome addition to any RPG fans collection, it's also worth noting you can play it entirely with mouse clicks (I found this to be really rather nice for a laptop owner). Seriously, just buy it!

reviewText:
In short - this game is absolutely awesome.
In long... Challenging yet not impossible, funny yet smart - it keeps you playing, but never lets you get bored.
Personally I find fighting mechanics extremely enjoyable - well balanced, but requiring some level of skill to end up effective and successful. Storyline is nice, though I liked it more in EBF3 - there were more fun stuff and I really loved all those witty anime refferals. I want to point out - that in EBF4 quality level DID NOT drop, it's just that now such things are expected (for those who played previous part obviously).
Characters are great - they are not one bit like classic boring heroic" heroes or angsty anime kids. Well... there are some problems - Lance with his naz... black uniform does look a bit disturbing. I just don't understand authors position on this one. So I picked different outfit and tried to forget. =) And did I say Natalie got some classy eyes
date: -wink -wink?!\n\nI recommend this game to everyone...  unless you find Final Fantasy style of battle system unaccepatable. If so - accept my condolences!"

reviewText:
This game is nothing short of perfect!
I used to play EBF back when it was on gaming websites such as Armor Games, and now I am really pleased to this

reviewText:
This game is undoubtedly one of the best flash games I played. The amount of work done to this game is phenomenal. I remember playing this on Kongregate and enjoying the hell out of it. Once I heard that the full version of the game was selling on steam, I told myself that I had to buy this. AND I played through the whole thing, including through all of the additional contents with Battle Mountain! Here's why this game is worth a look!

POSITIVES:
- HOURS of content
- Not so serious story with humorous elements of characters
- Four characters to play as (Each with unique skills)
- Many ways to customize characters (Skills, Costumes, Badges)
- Several areas to explore and tons of foes to face!
- Game presents a challenge and difficulty scales gradually
- Many RPG elements that people who are familiar OR new to them will love
- Many rewards, many prizes!
- Don't need to grind this game in order to beat it. From what I remember correctly, enemies scale to your level.
- SOUNDTRACK IS AMAZING!
- Art design of world and characters are attractive
- Can save your game anytime
- ACHIEVEMENTS!

NEGATIVES:
- No gripping or remarkable story
- For people who do not like casual RPGs, this is not your cup of tea

Overall, I enjoyed playing through this game again and experiencing the challenge of Battle Mountain! Hope this review helps make a clear picture of Epic Battle Fantasy 4!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a standard RPG with its selling point probably being its humor. It's pretty addicting.

The two best things about this game:

- When you get a medal, notifications appear on your steam client, the game itself (satisfying sound effect included), and if you have ASTATS open in your browser in the background, it'll appear there, too.

- What's even better, is when in game, you're fighting an enemy and it barely lived as your turn ended, then it gets struck by lightning and dies, ending the battle. Or even better, it gets crushed by a falling mammoth out of nowhere. Or two of them.

If you feel that's underwhelming, maybe this isn't for you. I recommend you play the free flash games, Epic Battle Fantasy 1~4, to see how you like it before buying it. They're on Kongregate and other flash game sites.

reviewText:
EBF originates from a internet flash game which I originally played years ago on Newgrounds. It's a turn-based adventure RPG with elements from its counterparts in both western RPGs and JRPGs.

As far as RPGs go, it has a relatively small amount of gameplay, making it a short (but in my opinion sweet) play. Most of the fun will be had in battles, where diverse enemies and an easy-to-understand element system make it a strangely relaxing experience. The art is nice, the moves are diverse and there are references everywhere to almost anything.

Its cheap too, so thats a plus.

reviewText:
~Epic Battle Fantasy 4~

I bought this game on a sale around 2$ , with no expectations from it , but when i actually played the game i found my self completely loving it! At first it's a bit boring but when the real battles and the easter eggs come ♥♥♥♥ get real.
i really enjoyed the gameplay , it was not too slow but not fast either. The art style was amazing and the colours were just so pretty. The movement is really annoying in the begging untill you understand how it works. The plot is so over the top that it actually gets intresting at some points. The gameplay time , if you play with side missions, farming exp and gold , finding rare armor etc. , and try to finding all the easter eggs will be about 40-50 hours, if you play only the main story line it will be around 15-20 hours. And finally , last but not least , the achievements, OMG those achievements, you must jiggle natalie's boobs and find pants! To sum up this game is mostly focused on oldschool rpg fans but new players can also enjoy it but not as much.

Overall score : 8,5/10

reviewText:
A must-buy, must-play game.

I highly suggest playing the first Epic Battle Fantasy games (you can find those online) for the sake of the storyline and getting to know some of the characters.

This game made me laugh out loud more than once with its fourth-wall breaking and really bad jokes.
The gameplay itself is absolutely fantastic in every conceivable way. It's smooth, engaging, and there are a lot of challenges that'll keep you on your seat for a long, long time (from puzzles to bosses on Epic difficulty). The artwork is cute, and so is the plot. And finally, the characters are absolutely lovable and memorable, with each one having a unique (and sometimes unusual) personality.

One of the best games I've ever played, and though it will probably not come out, I do hope that Matt creates an Epic Battle Fantasy 5. I really wanna get to know Anna more as a character, and I kinda wanna see some possibility of some relationships blooming!

reviewText:
Boy, did I strike gold when I picked up Epic Battle Fantasy 4.  New to the series I had no Idea what I was getting myself in to, but it quickly found a warm and fuzzy place in this avid RPG fan's heart.

The art style in this game offers a fun, playful experience, keeping well away from the dark and gritty with generous amounts of color to satisfy everyones pallet.  The Soundtrack. MY GOD THE SOUNDTRACK is what makes this game for me. The various battle themes keep you pumped from start to finish and with every new zone comes its own thrilling and whimsical theme tune that serenades you on your fantasy adventure and well after that. Going by the music and game design alone, it is clear that the developers and those involved in this humble indie game have a  clear understanding of both fun and fantasy.

The ammount of  hours you can get out of this game is up to you. With an endless supply of monsters showing up in previously explored areas, you can level your characters as much or as little as you like. The enviroment puzzles, although optional will keep you busy and reward you fairly.  Oh and feel free to grind materials and upgrade your gear for  even more of an edge in battle.
And I can confidently say this game has plenty of replayability, the main story is short and sweet and wont run the risk of boring you halfway through your second, even third playthrough. You have some control over what abilities your characters learn or not, and mixing up the gear and permenant upgrades to your characters stats can certainly effect their roles and the outcome of battles. Plus multiple difficulty settings for all your bragging-rights needs!

A damn fine Fantasy RPG that will amaze, inspire and reward your efforts with equal affection.

Guaranteed satisfaction 10/10

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4...truly a wonderful nod to the RPG's of old, and filled to the brim with personality, humor, and references everywhere. The game plays like a traditional RPG, where you walk around the world, find items in chests, complete a few quests for NPC's (and by 'quest', I mean go and find them some junk and bring it back), and fight enemies.

Of course, there is a deeper play to it. Anyone who has played the prior Epic Battle Fantasy games on Flash game sites such as Armorgames or Kongregate will know that equipping the right stuff is key to the game, and even armor and items you find early on may play key roles later on, especially if you upgrade them. No weapon or armor is useless in this game, and it allows for a good amount of customization. Plus, the proper armor and weapons show up on the character as you switch them, which is a fine little bonus~

And for those who are skeptical of buying this knowing that there is indeed a Free-to-Play version out there, the money is well worth the spending, because you're not only supporting the creator of this fine series (kudos to you, Matt Rozak), but you get some extra content in the form of new weapons/armor, new summons, and a tough optional area that will test your skills in more ways than one. Plus you get the soundtrack to boot~

Overall, it's a very good game, especially for one made in Flash. If you're looking for a light-hearted RPG, this may just be the one for you.~

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is the latest game in the series of flash driven, turn based RPGs by Kupo Games. Its tiny development team, headed by Matt Roszak (Whom is credited for design, art, story and programming).

This is a game which should be praised, for the amount of effort put in. The result is a well realised and full RPG experience full of character and heart.

The game retains enough nostalgia from old school RPGs but still manages to feel fresh and new. If you’ve ever played any Final Fantasy title pre FFXI you’ll be familiar with this format.
It gives a master class in how a turn based system should play along with all the usual elements you’d expect, being able to cast magic, summon other creatures, use items and attack and it does this as well as any JRPG does. Its appeal for me was that this is a finely tuned machine of a game. Usually with turn-based RPGs you eventually become so powerful that nothing is really a challenge, except maybe some bosses but with a combination of a difficulty slider that makes a difference and some well paced scaling of foes, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 keeps you on your toes and makes you think a little bit.

I’ve always loved turn based RPGs when done well and RPGs in general, but turn based more so than Action. The reason being it brings an element of strategy with out reliance on quick time events [which i hate]. Epic Battle Fantasy 4 makes full use of the strategic element of the genre.

It does this through its use of equipment and skills. The majority of weapons have an elemental effect which will assist you in tearing through enemies that are weak to that element and each piece of equipment has a use, without the collect and discard method used in most games. Weapons can be swapped out in combat also but this will take up a valuable turn to do so. Not only that, you won’t be receiving that free ride through an area.

The skill and specials pool is a very well implemented way of customising your characters and their skillset. Skills can only be learned by that specific character and specials can be learned by all, but only one character may have it at any one time. Once again, brings some difficult decisions forward. You can also equip the characters with items that will provide passive bonuses or abilities within battle, another little customisable option for balancing your team some buffing characters and some casting abilities at dice-rolled intervals. Gone, in this game, is any idea of an “Ultimate” weapon. For me, that’s refreshing. Each weapon can be upgraded as you collect items from combat or treasure.

The characters are well written and interact nicely. The personalities feel genuine and It seems like they are inspired by or based in some way on friends of the developer. At times they do act like close friends who have a lot of fun in each other’s company. This game is no doubt a labour of love and the small team at Kupo Games must have poured a lot of time into this game. It is increasingly rare to see triple-A games give this creative warmth, probably due to the size of the teams but Steam lets this flourish.

There are a lot of small gestures and references that experienced RPG fans will appreciate showing a good dose of humour. From the snow covered Djinn from Golden Sun in Whitefall Town to the name of some of the achievements you can gain for using new items they flow through the whole game well.

Epic Battle Fantasy’s achievement/medal system is well implemented. Some are very difficult to obtain, some pretty much laughing in the face at how ridiculous achievement systems are. When combined with the bestiary gives you that feeling of collection that a lot of games look past. It makes you want to collect them, this is important.

A game by a turn-based RPG fan, for turn-based RPG fans, this will likely not appeal to those who only play Shooters or Wii Fit games but give it a chance and it may well draw you in.

To wrap up, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is an absolutely fantastic game, made even more impressive by the huge contribution by Matt Roszak.
It is a game i’ve played over the Christmas holidays and will likely play again soon. With a Newgame+ option it is set up well for this. The art is soft and friendly, the enemies range from menacing to adorable. The mechanics are solid, the story is well written, the characters engaging and the experience is enjoyable.


It can also be bought for next to nothing because ‘Steam’.

4 Ferrets out of 5

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is the latest game in the series of flash driven, turn based RPGs by Kupo Games. Its tiny development team, headed by Matt Roszak (Whom is credited for design, art, story and programming).

This is a game which should be praised, for the amount of effort put in. The result is a well realised and full RPG experience full of character and heart.

The game retains enough nostalgia from old school RPGs but still manages to feel fresh and new. If you’ve ever played any Final Fantasy title pre FFXI you’ll be familiar with this format.
It gives a master class in how a turn based system should play along with all the usual elements you’d expect, being able to cast magic, summon other creatures, use items and attack and it does this as well as any JRPG does. Its appeal for me was that this is a finely tuned machine of a game. Usually with turn-based RPGs you eventually become so powerful that nothing is really a challenge, except maybe some bosses but with a combination of a difficulty slider that makes a difference and some well paced scaling of foes, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 keeps you on your toes and makes you think a little bit.

I’ve always loved turn based RPGs when done well and RPGs in general, but turn based more so than Action. The reason being it brings an element of strategy with out reliance on quick time events [which i hate]. Epic Battle Fantasy 4 makes full use of the strategic element of the genre.

It does this through its use of equipment and skills. The majority of weapons have an elemental effect which will assist you in tearing through enemies that are weak to that element and each piece of equipment has a use, without the collect and discard method used in most games. Weapons can be swapped out in combat also but this will take up a valuable turn to do so. Not only that, you won’t be receiving that free ride through an area.

The skill and specials pool is a very well implemented way of customising your characters and their skillset. Skills can only be learned by that specific character and specials can be learned by all, but only one character may have it at any one time. Once again, brings some difficult decisions forward. You can also equip the characters with items that will provide passive bonuses or abilities within battle, another little customisable option for balancing your team some buffing characters and some casting abilities at dice-rolled intervals. Gone, in this game, is any idea of an “Ultimate” weapon. For me, that’s refreshing. Each weapon can be upgraded as you collect items from combat or treasure.

The characters are well written and interact nicely. The personalities feel genuine and It seems like they are inspired by or based in some way on friends of the developer. At times they do act like close friends who have a lot of fun in each other’s company. This game is no doubt a labour of love and the small team at Kupo Games must have poured a lot of time into this game. It is increasingly rare to see triple-A games give this creative warmth, probably due to the size of the teams but Steam lets this flourish.

There are a lot of small gestures and references that experienced RPG fans will appreciate showing a good dose of humour. From the snow covered Djinn from Golden Sun in Whitefall Town to the name of some of the achievements you can gain for using new items they flow through the whole game well.

Epic Battle Fantasy’s achievement/medal system is well implemented. Some are very difficult to obtain, some pretty much laughing in the face at how ridiculous achievement systems are. When combined with the bestiary gives you that feeling of collection that a lot of games look past. It makes you want to collect them, this is important.

A game by a turn-based RPG fan, for turn-based RPG fans, this will likely not appeal to those who only play Shooters or Wii Fit games but give it a chance and it may well draw you in.

To wrap up, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is an absolutely fantastic game, made even more impressive by the huge contribution by Matt Roszak.
It is a game i’ve played over the Christmas holidays and will likely play again soon. With a Newgame+ option it is set up well for this. The art is soft and friendly, the enemies range from menacing to adorable. The mechanics are solid, the story is well written, the characters engaging and the experience is enjoyable.


It can also be bought for next to nothing because ‘Steam’.

4 Ferrets out of 5

reviewText:
Wow this game is good.
It is probably my favorite RPG of 2014.

It's deep, it's solid and it is as easy or hard as you want it to be. Like Bravely Default you can switch difficulty at any time with no consequence. If I had one wish, it would be that the game was on a better engine with better presentation and that more people heard of this game because it is truely an underrated classic.

reviewText:
I freakin' love this game.  Before I get into the controversial stuff that I like... let me just say that the battle system in this game is amazing.  You can decide which characters get which special moves, you can level skills up that you want while leaving others in the dust if you choose, you have to level up your equipment (especially in later battles) to ensure you have a nice diverse set of resist gear to survive the challenging boss fights (depending on the difficulty you set it on).

Did I mention that there are tons of hidden chests, quests for npcs (that aren't necessary for progression, just a bonus), an extra difficult bonus location for those of us that bought the game, and an amazing sound track?

I personally really got a kick out of some of the commentary between the characters.  The story is obviously very light-hearted and the gimmicky chats between the heroes is usually comical - not to mention you can click on Natalie for a chuckle now and then.

Epic Battle Fantasy 4 for me was a breath of fresh air in a market that no longer caters to those of us who liked the traditional jrpg such as the early FF games/nes/snes rpgs of the past.  I like Skyrim and all of the clones of that new genre of rpg that are out, but I REALLY like the old style.  As someone who grew up in the 80s and 90s playing the rpgs of that time, and if you did too, you will like this game.

Thank you so much Kupo for putting this together, I just wish EBF5 was out...

reviewText:
Almost to the end of the story, I think. I love jrpgs and there aren't that many good ones on Steam or the PC for that matter. But then there is EBF4. The story isn't much to write home about but it's still cute and the writing is pretty humorous with tons of references to other classic games.  The world is pretty big and each area is unique and has plenty of different types of monsters. Crafting is simple and straightforward but satisfying and there are tons of skills to choose from.

I have two very big complaints however. There is no controller support. Which is a shame because I wanted to sit back and relax whilst playing. The other complaint is the UI is a little cluttered. Even after hundreds of battles I can't remember which menu a specific skill is in but that's probably just because I'm dumb.

Either way the game is well worth the money and I'm will be playing it any time I need to satisfy my jrpg urges.

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4...truly a wonderful nod to the RPG's of old, and filled to the brim with personality, humor, and references everywhere. The game plays like a traditional RPG, where you walk around the world, find items in chests, complete a few quests for NPC's (and by 'quest', I mean go and find them some junk and bring it back), and fight enemies.

Of course, there is a deeper play to it. Anyone who has played the prior Epic Battle Fantasy games on Flash game sites such as Armorgames or Kongregate will know that equipping the right stuff is key to the game, and even armor and items you find early on may play key roles later on, especially if you upgrade them. No weapon or armor is useless in this game, and it allows for a good amount of customization. Plus, the proper armor and weapons show up on the character as you switch them, which is a fine little bonus~

And for those who are skeptical of buying this knowing that there is indeed a Free-to-Play version out there, the money is well worth the spending, because you're not only supporting the creator of this fine series (kudos to you, Matt Rozak), but you get some extra content in the form of new weapons/armor, new summons, and a tough optional area that will test your skills in more ways than one. Plus you get the soundtrack to boot~

Overall, it's a very good game, especially for one made in Flash. If you're looking for a light-hearted RPG, this may just be the one for you.~

reviewText:
A game like this is quite commonly found, but this game makes it more original with the humor, characters, and gameplay.


There's an adventure aspect to it, probably the most important part, where you have to move around the map and get to the next area.
There's a turn-based fighting part, which includes bosses, mini-bosses, and just enemies. There's buffs and debuffs, along with amazing attacks that deal massive damage, and a character-special 'final smash' move.
You can level up and upgrade your attacks, while increasing health and mana.
Upgrade your weapons with materials found on your journey, or bought from a local town.
Permanently upgrade stats with unique and rare foods to help in battle.
Find key items to help progress through the map.
Blatant love for cats!


I could go on and on, it's full of great features!
TLDR: This game is amazing, funny, interactive, and mixes all types of gameplay, with several unique aspects!
9/10

reviewText: I wanted an old-style ff-esque game.  This is that game.  It has an overworld scrolling map like the original zelda, along with the ability to avoid random encounters.  The backtracking to grab items is handled well in items you find throughout the game unlocking easy access to already explored areas.  The puzzles make you think from time to time, and are solvable without having to look up a solution online.  The only thing I wish I had done was make better use of all the different weaponry and items.  It's easy to just level up your favorite items and miss out on some great combat tactics.\n\nI got the game on sale, but I think this game is well worth the normal asking price.  If the author creates and epic battle fantasy 5, I will definitely be a buyer.

reviewText:
Oh boy, the Epic Battle Fantasy series came to Steam, always enjoyed this series, one of my favorites, especially EBF3 and 4.

Gameplay: Turn based RPG, Roam around the world, talk to people, do quests, kill stuff, etc. It's pretty much Final Fantasy.

Story: Gems of towns are stolen and Anna thinks that Matt and his friends stole them, but they aren't as the cat civilization are trying to revive a god.

Difficulty: You are in for hell if you play on any difficulty besides normal or easy, this game is very hard on the higher difficulties.

Characters: Alot of comedy with these characters here, tons of 4th wall breaks, oh well.

Overall: One of the best, I would play again. 10/10

Overall: 10/10
Music: 10/10
Characters:9/10
Story:9.5/10
Gameplay:10/10
Difficulty:8/10

I didn't know what to write about in my review, so here's a recipe for pancakes instead:

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
1 tablespoon white sugar
1 1/4 cups milk
1 egg
3 tablespoons butter, melted

1. In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

reviewText:
Eh.

I liked EBF3 better.

I've been following this game series for a long time now, so when EBF3 came out it 'wowed' me in a way that EBF4 simply cannot - being that it's exactly the same game, but with a new character (who doesn't add to the max count of players on the field). It feels like a new game. But, at the same time, I suppose instead of innovating, it's simply... more content. Coupled with a map that's of a decent size, yet feels surprisingly small. That, and of all the swords that we've got still in the game even from EBF1, no Soul Eater. My absolute favourite sword is not here. That makes me a very sad cookie. Soul Eater, featured in every game up until but excepting this one. Very fun because of the drastic reduction in survivability stats, but a huge increase in damage.

I'm only 17 hours in, at the final boss, and I expect to be here for a while longer, simply because I'm gonna need to grind up a whole bunch more XP off... something, and a whole bunch more money, off... something, since I expect I am going to need a pile of it to upgrade every piece of equipment I need so I can finally beat the boss.

Now let's get something straight. I don't mind grinding. I play Disgaea 1. Yeah, play. Not played. I'm still going.

But in EBF4... for some reason, I'm not really enjoying the grinding. I'm not really certain why. I spent hours upon hours finishing up EBF3, and it was incredibly satisfying to finally tick every box, but with EBF4, I'm struggling to work up the effort to beat the final boss.

Why do I recommend this game?

I recommend it because it's a good game. It really is. It's a $12 JRPG-type game, it's great fun, and it's terribly, wonderfully simple in scope. It's exactly what it looks like, a turn-based JRPG. If you like turn-based JRPGs, you will like this one.

If your finger is hovering over that 'Add To Cart' button, and you're just not sure, then give Epic Battle Fantasy 3 a go. It's free, and a good representation of what you're going to find if you purchase EBF4.

reviewText:
Quite enjoyable, and very nostalgic as I had played the previous three installments which were flash games. Reminiscent of the RPGs of old, with unique new twists. Offers an arcadey experience with a plot as intricate as the Mario franchise, so you don't really need to worry about getting caught up or anything since anywhere you start is pretty much all you really need to know.
Like I said, a very arcade experience for those who want good, strategic combat out of their RPGs. Multiple difficulty levels which can be changed outside of combat. Alot of the game will be you having epic combat in a fantasy setting, but I suppose the title could have told you that much.

This game gives plenty of replay value, despite the 28 hours I clocked in at the time of this review, I haven't finished a single playthrough yet. Provided, I did alot of mucking about with sidequesting and took my sweet time, and if I went straight for the final boss things could have been done quicker, but this game features a whole host of battles that aren't part of the main map and further enhances the whole arcade" view point.

reviewText:
Wow, this game is fun... and big! I'm amazed it's just a Flash game. If you're a fan of the old-school Final Fantasy games, this game is for you, especially if you like cats. :3 It's very rewarding, too, since the visuals are fantastic, the writing is fun, and the battles are tense (especially toward the end). I can't count the number of times when I was sure I was going to lose, but I somehow managed to get it together just enough to crawl to victory.

The final boss is the most tense battle I've ever fought in an RPG. The game does its best to kill you, but there's this tiny sliver of hope, and every turn feels like it will be your last. When victory finally comes, you will know it's because you tore it from the the maw of defeat with your bare hands.

At least, that's how I felt. Hopefully, I'm not just bad. :P I'm sure I could have leveled up more, but the pacing of the game made it feel like this was where I was supposed to be, and that feeling persists through the entire game. Grinding is minimal, and I only did it when I just felt like bashing some heads in for fun.

Get it. Get it, now!

reviewText:
If you are considering whether to buy this game, there are a couple of points to consider:
Firstly, are you a fan of flash RPGs with a hint of humour?
Secondly, will you like electronically generated background music?
Thirdly, do you enjoy extensive map area (eg. exploring and appreciating graphics of game world) ?

If your answer is Yes for either of the questions above, then you Should buy this game! Don't let the price tag deter you. This game is fun, and epic that I spent 3 years enjoying it, from when it was first released on Kongregate. The game is the combination of it free-mium version on Kongregate + guns/swords/wands/bows and many more!

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 despite its quirks is a reasonably well made JRPG with a solid combat system that comes with interesting itemization(optimization for fights ahoy!). Sadly I found the story rather lacking. Obviously it makes fun of many stereotypes in the genre and overal tries to make jabs at how easy our heroes mow through zones while npc's pretend like it's all ever so hard...

In the end I cannot help but feel that the lack of any kind of story to get invested into really hurts the game since it really only has the gameplay going for it. When a serious game makes a joke or two you can really appreciate them since they contrast with the serious nature of the game. Epic Battle Fantasy 4 sadly makes a joke out of everything which ends up making everything unfunny.

So is the game worth playing? I bought it for about €3,00 or so and I'd say the 25 hours I got out of it were easily worth it. Get it at a discount and you'll have fun without trying to justify the price. I enjoyed the game since it has solid combat and itemization but it's not going to be something people will talk about much since storytelling is often such a strong part of JRPG's and it simply hurts the game not having much of any.

reviewText:
I love RPGs. Jrpgs, western rpgs, they're both awesome.

I saw the trailer for this game, read some reviews, and I was sold.

Unfortunately, my first (and last) impression of the game was so bad, that I regret having paid for this title.

The interface is terribly cluttered, difficult to use and understand.

There is NO tutorial in the beginning. None. There are some vague hints here and there about minor aspects of the game, but that's it.

How to fight? How to find your way? How to manage your inventory and skills?

Not explained in any way. Hell, I even had a hard time figuring out where the hell I was supposed to go to begin with!

I'm all for games that don't hold your hand (God bless Dark Souls), but this game, despite being a Jrpg, seemed to make it obscenely hard for me to even start going somewhere.

Unless you have the patience of a saint and the willingness to figure where the hell you're supposed to go to, and how to do ANYTHING, I recommend staying away from this title.

I regret buying it.

reviewText:
I've been playing these games since the very beginning, and played 4 when I was testing it on deviantart. This is by far the best one yet, even if I do miss some of the sweet equipment from 3.

Very funny game, charming with a sweet array of enemies and abilities for each character, plus a fourth character that isn't in any previous game. (Not-So) Subtle references abound to various other games and anime, and the steam version adds features that even earlier versions of the same game did not have.

Quite similar to the classic 90's RPG games, you'll think final fantasy primarily. And like any good Turn Based RPG, it's a thinker's game, great for those who love attention to tactics.

I'd reccomend any of these games, any day, play the earlier ones for free, and drop a little cash for this one. Thumbs up~

reviewText: This game, while a pretty traditional story-driven turn-based rpg, really stands out for it's art and attitude to the conventions of the genre.  The constant lampshading of rpg and video game tropes and humerous dialog keep it going strong when interest in the story fails (as it inevitably does) and the combat gets repetetive.  This isn't a game to binge-play, but more of something to do when you don't want anything too exciting or gritty.

reviewText: I can't say enough good things about this game.  If you like turn-based, final fantasy style combat and RPG's that don't take themselves too seriously, then you'll really enjoy Epic Battle Fantasy 4. The music by HalcyonicFalconX is guaranteed to get stuck in your head too.\n\nThere's a free Flash demo you can try on your favorite webgames site. I put many hours into it before I discovered the complete version was available on Steam.

reviewText: First old school type JRPG i've played in a VERY long time, and it made me remember why I liked them so much.  Lots of options and depth to the game in terms of elements/stats/effects/gear, and the fact that you can make the 4 characters into almost any type of class you wants negates the fact that there's no real character variety.  The one real downside I will say is that the storyline and comedy really wasn't there for me.  Maybe some spots where it made me smile, but nothing resembling laughter or really funny moments.  Worth the purchase for the one play thru, plus if you like it a lot there's plenty to do after that like endless modes, marathon battles, and epic difficulty.

reviewText:
It's a great game. I've played all of the Epic Battle Fantasy games, and this one is my favorite. Despite my dislike of uncouth humor (and there is quite a bit of uncouth humor), I find this game to be quite enjoyable. And there is also humor that I do like, so there's that. There's more content here than you can get play in any short period of time.

It's a FInal Fantasy-esque game, so if you are familiar with that, it is easy enough to figure out. Click on this, click on that, enemies get exploded/shot/sliced/arrow'd/. Level up skills with skill points. Use items.

If I were to make one complaint, it would be that it doesn't have a Mac version. The dev said that it won't be happening for a while, so if you don't have a Windows computer, you might be out of luck.

Matt does, in fact, like swords. Even if they aren't actually swords.

reviewText: A unique, well-thought-out RPG featuring a classic battle systesm. With 4 difficulty options that can be swapped at any time, the game has appeal to all fans of the genre, whether you're a hardcore power leveler or just rushing through the mandatory battles, the combat is simple and with many skills to level at your command, battles become more reliant on your own decisions. The dialog both in combat and in the field is witty and surprisingly well written, though some dialogues can be misplaced if missed in an earlier fight. The art in the game is fantastic - the character and enemy models are well-drawn and all have a distinct EBF artstyle. Each piece of equipment modifies the character models enabling the player to decide what their character stats will be and cool or cute they look. The story mode is fairly lengthy, taking anywhere from 15-25 hours on a normal difficulty run depending on completion and grind and features several optional challenges, with massive replayability including New Game + and Battle Island. Last but not least the music, by HalcyonicFalconX is not only great, but each piece fits amazingly with the nature of the battle or field, making the entire RPG experience phenomenal.

reviewText:
EBF4 is a fantastic JRPG with very nice aesthetics, fun & strategic turn-based gameplay, and lots of references to make you smirk even a bit. The entire series is pretty good, but EBF4 takes the same elements from the previous games and improves on them in every way. You can play it for free on Kong, but the paid version has some extra content and it supports the devs. If you like turn-based combat with a side of cats, jigges ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°), and gr8 banter, you'll truly enjoy this gem.

EBF5 pls :D

Edit: Btw, the game's soundtrack is quite phenomenal. You'll enjoy that too.

reviewText:
Very tight combat mechanics with a lot of interacting skills, status effects, and equipment.  The depth of customization here is stupendous.  It keeps the combat fresh and only becomes tedious near the end if you need to power-level your way up to handle the extremely formidable bosses.  Interesting characters, tons of loot, and the diverse combat mechanics keep the game engaging all the way to the end.

Graphics are anime-style rendered in a flash engine.  Not exactly crysis, but it doesn't want to be, and it fits the feel of the game perfectly.

The dialogue is humorous - adolescent and boob-focused, but again, this game doesn't care about that and neither should you.  It knows what it wants to be and does it great.

reviewText:
Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a upbeat, funny and lovable game. It has great humour, interesting and well thought out characters and a fun storyline. The battles have lots of different factors to consider e.g. enemy types, weapon types, atacks, equips, etc. and you really get engrossed in figuring out what skills and types you need and where. Each character Anna, Matt, Natalie and Lance all have unique personalities and styles and you can customise the abilities they have to a certain degree which really lets you feel involved with the team.

All in all you will spend hours playing and forget how long you are at your pc until an annoyed relative comes and tells you to try talking to people instead of sitting around all day, to which you reply 'Never!' and carry on playing this amazing game!

Also as an added bonus Matt Roszak (the Developer, Publisher and Creator) has included wallpapers and the soundtrack in the local files of the game! Which is awesome as the soundtrack is one of my favourites!

P.S. I have more hours than it is displaying for a odd reason... oh well!

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
[[ TL;DR Version: EBF4 getting a Steam release is real justice being made, buy it ]]

I've been a fan of the Epic Battle Fantasy since I first found the original on Newgrounds five years ago. Seeing the series evolve as much as it has, finally reaching an actual release on Steam? It's a great sight.

I've never been a fan of JRPGs, but I never found EBF to be frustratingly difficult. It requires the right enough amount of micromanagement, planning, and strategy to appeal to both casual and hardcore RPG players. It's also got a very parody-minded sense of humor that's usually quite fun and rarely runs dry. One example in it's favor is South Park: The Stick of Truth, which I did like for it's humor, but the tongue-in-cheek delivery kind of killed it for me halfway. EBF doesn't do that, and I'm glad about that.

While my only real complaint would be the relative lack of backstory to cover the events of past games for those who might be new to these games, it's never so drawn out and overly complicated to not pick up on quickly. If you're looking for a new RPG to add to your library, I'd definitely make no higher recommendations.

reviewText:
I honestly could not stress how much I recommend this game to RPG enthusiasts. I played the Epic Battle Fantasy series when it was just an evolving flash series (with a really fun bullet hell offshoot) on Kongregate. I loved each and every iteration, and I loved EBF4 to the point I sat down and went full nerd-out on it with writing things down, calculating, minmaxing, the whole nerd-works. I loved it enough I actually put money towards the microtransaction it had. When I heard it was coming to Steam, I was super hype for it, but I never was able to get around to snatching it. Now that I have it, i've revisited it and am having just as much fun - if not more! - than I was on Kongregate.

The game itself is what I would call a tribute parody. The entire thing is self-aware of its genre, but also faithful to what it's parodying. Classic turn based combat with a rock-paper-scissors elemental / buff / debuff system, many items to equip to this end, a buttload of spells and abilities both natural to each character AND others that can be passed between each. Saving on the fly, resuming on the fly, overworld monster encounters instead of the random encounters we all are used to from classic RPGs, and those monsters tend to disappear permanently if they areb locking your main path. The scanbot allows you quick reference mid-battle to what an enemy is capable of, while also giving you a permanent bestiary entry for later reference. There are plenty of other features that really speak that an RPG enthusiast is behind the development, who has gone through the caveats and annoying nuances that many RPGs over the years have tossed at us that plenty a gamer have thrown their hands up at in rage. There is an abundance of humor, including puns, references, tropes and similar things that make fun of itself and its genre, and also referring to other games, series, memes, etc. without being overbearing and causing you to roll your eyes.

tl;dr: This is an RPG made by, and for, RPG lovers, and I could honestly say you're missing out if you pass this up and are an avid player of RPGs.

reviewText: Epic Battle Fantasy 4 looks like a shallow game you would find on a smartphone at first glance. While it isn't that complex once you actually dig beneath the surface and start playing you quickly find a well crafted turn based RPG with a lot of good mechanics and customization. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Epic battle fantasy 4 was actually the best game I've played all year, hands down. Balanced but challenging gameplay, witty humor and a ton of innuendoes all thrown together into one RPG is a once in a lifetime game. I really enjoyed the strategy to it, especially the weapon and armor system. In EBF4, There isnt such thing as endgame armor or weapons. Its all balanced. The sword you start out with on matt will be useful for some battles, but not all. Likewise, a shiny new sword from a hard dungeon might be great at taking out certain foes, but not much else. The same goes for the games armor. Overall I give it a 10/10, and I highly reccomend it. Easily worth the cheap price tag. To be honest I'd say it worth much more. If you like a fun engaging game with a lot of references and jokes, pick it up!

reviewText:
Old school turn based RPG combat.

You play a girl from a village that had their idol statue stolen. 3 Heroes from the prior games (Not on PC all tablet) figured since they saved the world they are entitled to everything so they are on a mass pilfering spree. The villager finds them and beats them up only to find out that they did not steal the statue. The surrounding villages have also had their statues stolen. So now the 4 go out to try to find the theif.

For its simplistic look it is really a very good looking game. You can tell that this is a port from a tablet. The music is outstanding and is even available as a soundtrack. There is no voice dialog but the storyline and text dialog a great. The game makes fun of the whole RPG and Anime environment.  The characters are often making fun of each other and making jokes. Each character has a specialty and can learn most the others.

You have the main girl who does Earth damage, the second girl (the pretty one") who uses advanced magic and anime style heals
date: a techno guy who uses guns and has a tank
recommended: and the last guy who does mostly direct damage "meat shield".\n\nThe game looks simplistic and will quickly ramp up in difficulty. Definitely a great turn based RPG game to have."

reviewText:
As someone who pretty much grew up with the EBF series I would highly recommend this, along with Matt's 3rd game if you're interested in why everyone loves this game to bits. Not to say the first two are bad imo, since they still have their special place in my flash gaming days, way back 8 years ago.

EBF is ultimately a tribute to the classic 16-bit Final Fantasy games, but it has its own unique style with its art and its cheesy yet delightful humor. The game has come a long way since its times without an overworld, NoLegs spam and trying to defeat final boss Goku. But I believe EBF 4 really shows the peak of Matt's RPG making skills.

It's well balanced with addictive gameplay that's simple and features likeable characters, adorable enemies, cool bosses and a fun, quirky story. This is definitely my favorite indie game and i recommend you at least check it out if you're interested.

reviewText:
This game is a joke, being a parody of Final Fantasy,
BUT
It's not a joke.

Not only does this include a difficulty system that actually tells you everything major that changes (Besides things like the Bomb Slimes and Purple Squids entering battle with nine poison stacks on Epic) but the game is still reasonably difficult without putting it on Epic, unless you're so used to Epic that in your second playthrough on on a sequential save half of the enemies one-shotting you in the power plant due to you being two levels underleveled feels normal. My first experience with Epic was nearly getting killed on the first battle in the game, gg. What truly makes this game difficult is Epic is insanely hard, but you can adapt to it. You can get hit by the enemies and survive, and most things that the enemies can do aren't out of your power, unlike a lot of games you see today. It puts the player and the enemies on nearly equal ground, but manages to still keep the game reasonably difficult. That is a sign that the game's difficulty is well designed.

This game contains parodic references to almost every game in the book that your childhood was composed of. reviewText:
It's a very good game for it's price if you don't take it too seriously.

The game is very easy (specially if you compare it to some old rpgs) but the gameplay is fun with no random encounters (you can still powerlevel by leaving the area and coming back).

It has a simple UI, easy to understand and allows you to battle faster than in other turn-based rpgs.

Nice crafting system, very simple but effective, only really needed to play on max difficulty (where you get most steam achievements)

Don't expect too much from the storyline though.

Fun game overall to spend some hours. (I'd recomend using some sort of speedhack like in most rpgs if you plan on powerleveling)

reviewText:
Been playing the since the first Epic Battle Fantasy on Kongregate.com. Was not disappointed by this.

You will play as 4 characters each with their own themes and skills that match. You start with 1 and quickly collect the rest of your party.

Minor spoiler for party formation if you play previous games:  You start as the new game character instead of any of the original characters.

Combat is really simple yet can be indept. There are attacks and spells, buffs and debuffs, resistances and weaknesses. Enemies have attack patterns which can be predictable at times.

There are numerous pots. Equipment wise, you can equip a weapon, a headgear (hat), an armor, and 3 flairs (badges for small bonuses). While you can not craft any items, you can upgrade them to improve their existing stats and sometimes add new ones.

Story is cheeky and predictable. Humor is the same as previous games.

Overall buy it if you like a decent rpg.

This is...well...AMAZING. I'm not a big fan of jRPGs in general (although to be fair I like quite a few of the old SNES ones) and I bought this game during a sale. I wasn't expecting much. If you like jRPGs (or RPGs in general) and don't mind the humor I heartly recommend buying this game! Right Now!

A few remarks:
- Good, if repetitive combat
- Funny dialog
- Good art / art design.
- Took me about 14h to finish it
- I didn't encounter any bugs.

reviewText:
This game is a joke, being a parody of Final Fantasy,
BUT
It's not a joke.

Not only does this include a difficulty system that actually tells you everything major that changes (Besides things like the Bomb Slimes and Purple Squids entering battle with nine poison stacks on Epic) but the game is still reasonably difficult without putting it on Epic, unless you're so used to Epic that in your second playthrough on on a sequential save half of the enemies one-shotting you in the power plant due to you being two levels underleveled feels normal. My first experience with Epic was nearly getting killed on the first battle in the game, gg. What truly makes this game difficult is Epic is insanely hard, but you can adapt to it. You can get hit by the enemies and survive, and most things that the enemies can do aren't out of your power, unlike a lot of games you see today. It puts the player and the enemies on nearly equal ground, but manages to still keep the game reasonably difficult. That is a sign that the game's difficulty is well designed.

This game contains parodic references to almost every game in the book that your childhood was composed of. My favorite cluster of references is the graveyard in Graybone Cemetery, there are many tombstones on one screen, a few of them are damaged, but the ones that aren't contain jokes that are mostly references of some sort. This is only a pinch of what is included in the actual game, though.

The dialogue in this game somehow keeps a decent balance between Absolutely hilarious and cannot be taken seriously" and "Deep storyline" despite the final boss being *SPOILER* a cat god.
