reviewText:
You'll notice that I'm here on Steam. That's because of this gem! I got a steam account strictly to get this game! This game is the classic RPG that people like Square seem to have forgotten how to make. It has a twisted humor, great gameplay, greater replayability, battles that can range from laughable to.. well.. EPIC, and lets not forget that downright awe-inspiring soundtrack! Phyrnna (HalcyonicFalcon's work on Youtube, look her up, she does the music for all the EBF games) did an outstanding job. If your not dreading the final battle just by ear alone.. well..

The art is beautiful, the array of skills, customization, equipment, treasure hunting, and overall exploration is vast. If yer a hardcore collector in games, this is your thing! Honestly, I can't say anything terrible about it. It is just a great darn game.
I'd easily rate it 12/10 if I could!

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since the free version first came out. In fact, I have been playing this developer's games since the first Epic Battle Fantasy came out. I love each and every one of them, and I feel as though I cannot recommend this game enough.

First of all, the developer of this game is great. All of his work has proven to be incredibly entertaining and it just gets better and better with each game. The main reason I wanted to buy this game in the first place was to support him, and I am very happy with that decision.
This is one of the best RPGs I've played when it comes to the mechanics and gameplay. It is very entertaining and fun, and it is simple to learn. I love how the elements system works in the game and watching the animation for your new moves is always a reward too.
This version adds quite a bit to what I had originally played, and I love all of the added content. The new area and puzzles are fun, with the new fights being really well-done as well. The new skills and weapons are a nice bonus as well.

This game has so much to offer, and I am very glad I purchased it. Between all the customization options with characters moves and equipment, the battle system that can just be fun to watch, and all the new content, it would be hard for me to not recommend this to everyone.

reviewText:
[[ TL;DR Version: EBF4 getting a Steam release is real justice being made, buy it ]]

I've been a fan of the Epic Battle Fantasy since I first found the original on Newgrounds five years ago. Seeing the series evolve as much as it has, finally reaching an actual release on Steam? It's a great sight.

I've never been a fan of JRPGs, but I never found EBF to be frustratingly difficult. It requires the right enough amount of micromanagement, planning, and strategy to appeal to both casual and hardcore RPG players. It's also got a very parody-minded sense of humor that's usually quite fun and rarely runs dry. One example in it's favor is South Park: The Stick of Truth, which I did like for it's humor, but the tongue-in-cheek delivery kind of killed it for me halfway. EBF doesn't do that, and I'm glad about that.

While my only real complaint would be the relative lack of backstory to cover the events of past games for those who might be new to these games, it's never so drawn out and overly complicated to not pick up on quickly. If you're looking for a new RPG to add to your library, I'd definitely make no higher recommendations.

reviewText: Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is easily one of my most favorite games I have played. It has over 72 hours worth of game play(which is becoming more rare in newer games) and four difficulties for even further challenge. There are many skills you can learn in the game and some are character specific while some can be learned buy multiple characters to add strategy to the game. In addition to many skills, there are many different types of equipment, each with their own special effect and stats. Aside from the excellent game play, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 has great music that really sets the tone for the game in each area. Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is definetely worth the $12 since most games that have 24+ hours gameplay cost 5+ times as much. Very excited that the developer will be making an Epic Battle Fantasy 5. Will definetely buy that when it comes out.

reviewText:
Fun game. Continues the series. Same as the Flash game with the same name,

I have been playing this game for over 17 hours offline.

Pros:
- Great time killer.
- Gaming culture and fourth demension breaking gags everywhere.
- Interesting story.
- Some really odd quests...... women's underwear is a quest item.
- Got me to buy and play this game after I finished the Flash version.
- Great music.


Cons:
- Massive back track game, done somewhat well by restricting areas until the barriers are broken.
- A bit grindy sometimes. Take your time and bulk up.
- Music loops a bit too much in battle.
- Hard to think of cons for.
- Have I mentioned the back tracking? You have no idea do you?


Things to know:
- Most males will worship Nat, they will give all the buffs to her.
- Grind before obvious bosses.
- Go for normal skills over maxed out elemental skills.
- Save often.


Give it a go; combat wise it's better than Final Fantasy 13.

For hardcore RPG fans and also for newcomers to the genre, EBF4 delivers the very best in turn-based strategy.

reviewText: Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a fantastic RPG game that is very enjoyable for several reasons, of which include the large amount of customization that offers thousands of strategies, and the addition of destroying a whole lot of enemies. The aptly Battle Mountain contains battles that will test your strength, and reward you. I enjoy the series, and this installment is just about the very best so far, at least until Epic Battle Fantasy 5 comes out. If you enjoy a fun RPG game that isn't too serious, lots of ways to obliterate your foes and just a plain good time, this is the right game for you. Of course, the interface is not the easiest to navigate, and the lack of a tutorial is a bit messed-up, but before you try this game, you should try the Flash version of it, to see if you would want to spend money on it.

reviewText:
Been playing the since the first Epic Battle Fantasy on Kongregate.com. Was not disappointed by this.

You will play as 4 characters each with their own themes and skills that match. You start with 1 and quickly collect the rest of your party.

Minor spoiler for party formation if you play previous games:  You start as the new game character instead of any of the original characters.

Combat is really simple yet can be indept. There are attacks and spells, buffs and debuffs, resistances and weaknesses. Enemies have attack patterns which can be predictable at times.

There are numerous pots. Equipment wise, you can equip a weapon, a headgear (hat), an armor, and 3 flairs (badges for small bonuses). While you can not craft any items, you can upgrade them to improve their existing stats and sometimes add new ones.

Story is cheeky and predictable. Humor is the same as previous games.

Overall buy it if you like a decent rpg.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A really fun, and funny game. I'm surprised by just how much I enjoyed this.
The skills are cool, and some are amusing (Like dropping a tank on top of your enemies), and I was playing simply to unlock more skills to see what they were like.

There isn't a lot of dialogue, and most of it's just random comments from the characters when you use new attacks are find something new, etc. Although not really bad in a game like this, it'd be better if there was more story to it, no matter how much seriousness said story lacks.

It's not all that difficult if you play on normal, most enemies are some kind of creature crossed with an element, and so have weaknesses, you get a scan bot that lets you see said weaknesses so honestly as long as you don't forget to keep your weapons and skills diverse you're going to be fine. Each area generally has a focus on one or two elements, so you can focus on those with your weapons as well.

The shop so far has been pretty pointless. I've not completed it yet, but I've literally only bought a few coffees from it before a boss, you don't really use items enough to use up the ones you find, and the weapons you find are generally good as well. Getting materials for crafting is simply a case of grinding as well.

Better quests would be good, it seems all the npc's just want food, even just a kill n monsters" or something would keep it more interesting. Just going out and fighting is fun enough in itself though
date: so it's not really a big issue.\n\nI feel like I've complained a bit about it
hoursPlayed: the game is genuinly enjoyable

reviewText:
It's a very good game for it's price if you don't take it too seriously.

The game is very easy (specially if you compare it to some old rpgs) but the gameplay is fun with no random encounters (you can still powerlevel by leaving the area and coming back).

It has a simple UI, easy to understand and allows you to battle faster than in other turn-based rpgs.

Nice crafting system, very simple but effective, only really needed to play on max difficulty (where you get most steam achievements)

Don't expect too much from the storyline though.

Fun game overall to spend some hours. (I'd recomend using some sort of speedhack like in most rpgs if you plan on powerleveling)

reviewText:
This game is a joke, being a parody of Final Fantasy,
BUT
It's not a joke.

Not only does this include a difficulty system that actually tells you everything major that changes (Besides things like the Bomb Slimes and Purple Squids entering battle with nine poison stacks on Epic) but the game is still reasonably difficult without putting it on Epic, unless you're so used to Epic that in your second playthrough on on a sequential save half of the enemies one-shotting you in the power plant due to you being two levels underleveled feels normal. My first experience with Epic was nearly getting killed on the first battle in the game, gg. What truly makes this game difficult is Epic is insanely hard, but you can adapt to it. You can get hit by the enemies and survive, and most things that the enemies can do aren't out of your power, unlike a lot of games you see today. It puts the player and the enemies on nearly equal ground, but manages to still keep the game reasonably difficult. That is a sign that the game's difficulty is well designed.

This game contains parodic references to almost every game in the book that your childhood was composed of. My favorite cluster of references is the graveyard in Graybone Cemetery, there are many tombstones on one screen, a few of them are damaged, but the ones that aren't contain jokes that are mostly references of some sort. This is only a pinch of what is included in the actual game, though.

The dialogue in this game somehow keeps a decent balance between Absolutely hilarious and cannot be taken seriously" and "Deep storyline" despite the final boss being *SPOILER* a cat god.
I think my favorite thing about the dialogue in this game is either the fact that there is a one-liner for nearly every skill in the game
date: or the fact that dialogue can randomly trigger when walking around the map
recommended: and these times it's at it's funniest. There is one cluster of dialogue where Lance is staring at highschoolers and Natalie calls him a pedophile. Another is a conversation between Matt and Lance where Matt seems to be trying to explain to Lance that despite all the cameras he apparently has in his posession that he uses to stalk Natalie

The humon is great, bring that flash game interenet meme vibe that existed so much in 2008.

reviewText:
EBF 4 is a game about 3 kleptomanic heroes who accidentally endanger the entire world. Again.

This game features a very good artstyle, music and an excellent gameplay.

The combat in this game is made in a early RPG fashion - 3 heroes out of the 4 available are in active combat and it's turnbased.

It also does feature a high degree of customization as you can select the combination of your party and some of their respective skills yourself.

So, for anyone out there who is a fan of good old RPG-fun ... I do recommend this game for you.

reviewText: EBF 4 is a turn-based RPG inspired by games like Final Fantasy and Golden Sun. It's the first of the series to be on steam, as the others were browser games on websites like Kongregate and Armor Games. I  remember playing one of the EBF games, although I don't remember which one. I don't remember much, so I wasn't sure what to expect.\n\nThere are quite a few unique mechanics in EBF 4. reviewText: Let me start by saying it's definitely not worth full price, this just doesn't have enough content over the free version that's been available for years to be worth anywhere near $10. I got it for about $2.50 and at that price I heartily recommend it. Anyone who likes turn based fights like FF or Pokemon will enjoy this. The humor isn't bad although there are a lot of running jokes from the previous games, so if you're not into the series you probably won't be into this. 100% achievements in 25 hours pretty damn good for a flash game.\n\nOnly downsides are some performance issues due to being flash (usually can be fixed with a restart) and low replayability once you've done everything in the game once. NG+ is more of a grind for an achievement than a chance to play around with early enemies with end game skills and gear since the enemies scale with you from start to finish.
